Designed for brides seeking a halal nail color alternative to "halal nail polish." Convenient to apply and remove, halal press on nails are more compliant than halal nail polish. Truth is, water doesn't permeate halal nail polish without it sitting for more time than it takes to wash your hands. If it did, halal nail polish would simply wipe off with water.

 

Our "halal nails near me" choices beautifully complement your look. Say goodbye to searching for halal nail polish that's wudhu friendly and trust Hijabi Bridal for all your halal nail color needs. Apply in five minutes, remove in two! These glue tabs ensure your nails stay elegant and intact throughout your wedding festivities.

column6: Gold and Red Muslim Groom Outfits
column7:
Gold & Red Muslim Groom Outfit

 

Hijabi Bridal's Exquisite Mix-and-Match Palette

 

Elevate your wedding day with our Gold & Red Muslim Groom Outfits, a stunning combination of tradition and sophistication available at Hijabi Bridal. This carefully curated palette features a blend of rich gold and dark red, allowing you to create a unique ensemble that reflects your personal style.

 

The core of this collection includes opulent waistcoats intricately embroidered with gold thread, paired with luxurious kurta sets that add a touch of regal charm. Complementing these pieces are coordinating Mughal men's footwear (jutti), crafted from premium fabrics to ensure elegance throughout your celebration. Mix and match dark red and gold to complete your look!

For inspiration on choosing the perfect ensemble, explore our guide to Muslim groom wedding outfits. Discover the latest trends and styling tips to make your day unforgettable [Get Inspired Here.]

 

Why Choose Gold & Red?

Consider red and gold if you want to coordinate with the bride!
- Tradition & Elegance: Combine the auspiciousness of red with the opulence of gold for your Muslim wedding groom dress, the two colors used for the majority of traditional Muslim weddings.
- Versatile Mix-and-Match: Create multiple looks to match your bride with our coordinated sets.
- Craftsmanship: Enjoy premium maroon and red fabrics and intricate gold embroidery for unmatched comfort and style.

 

If your bride is wearing a red islamic wedding dress, browse our Red Muslim Wedding Shop for the color coordination.

 

At Hijabi Bridal, we specialize in providing Muslim wedding groom outfits that reflect sophistication and cultural pride. If you're looking for the perfect Muslim groom dress for your wedding, these outfits guarantee timeless elegance, embracing your most cherished moments. Find your ideal look at Hijabi Bridal and step confidently into your new chapter, knowing you're adorned in an attire that tells your story with grace and grandeur.

column7:
Green Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

This Green Muslim Wedding Sharara is a popular choice for bridal wear and for guests at weddings, as well as for other wedding functions like mehendi, walimah and engagement ceremonies. The regal look and ease of movement of these Muslim wedding dresses makes them ideal for long celebrations.

 

Unlike other green Muslim wedding outfits that have a skirt, this Green Muslim Wedding Sharara is a traditional three-piece ensemble consisting of a kurta or kameez (long or short top), a heavily flared pair of pants (sharara bottoms) and a dupatta. View our Green Bridal Collection for all options in this color.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 3.

 

Product Details for Green Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

Lightweight and airy, the net fabric in this sharara is used with heavy champagne-colored embroidery for a beautifully elegant touch. A somewhat crisp fabric, net is used to add volume and structure, often with embroidery that enhances its defined shape. Embellishments in champagne color are balanced between the pants and kurta with simple work on the dupatta for a cohesive ensemble in this Green Muslim Wedding Sharara. The pants and top are heavily embroidered in floral patterns. So the embroidery on this set ranges from subtle to elaborate.

 

Sizes are measured at the bust in inches:(XXS-34),(XS-36),(S-38),(M-40),( L-42),( XL-44) and (XL-46). The top length is 37-39 inches for these Muslim wedding dresses.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 3.

 

Green Muslim Wedding Sharara for Style and Comfort

 

The shararaâ€™s most significant cultural influence comes from the Muslim Mughal era in India, where it was a symbol of luxury, status and elegance among noblewomen and royalty. Its voluminous, flared silhouette and ornate embellishments reflected the grandeur of Mughal court fashion. Bridal shararas have deep cultural roots tracing back to the Mughal era and are especially popular among Muslim brides in South Asia as a green Muslim wedding outfit. 

 

Sharara dresses are especially preferred for occasions that call for traditional elegance and comfort. Shararas are preferred over other dresses for weddings, festive events and formal gatherings due to their comfort, elegance and rich cultural heritage. The signature wide-legged, flared pants are the defining feature, creating a graceful and dramatic look that distinguishes the bridal sharara from other ethnic outfits.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 3.

 

How to Personalize your Green Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

When you select a vibrant color like rich green, you can mix it with luxurious fabrics like georgette, silk for your dupatta and hijab. What about your hair?

 

  • This sharara begs for a braided crown, or just braids period for a regal, intricate look. Try braiding hair on both sides and pinning it across the crown, perfect for formal and traditional events, or wear a different braided updo.
     

  • To disguise your braided updo, you can wrap the hijab in a turban style for a chic, modern vibe! Or go for volume around the face. A graceful look, frame the hijab around your face with some volume on top by loosely wrapping or pleating the fabric, which pairs beautifully with the shararaâ€™s flared silhouette and makes braids less noticeable under your hijab.
     

  • Because your main dupatta is understated, wear a second dupatta with detailed embroidery, sequins, or a rich border to serve as a focal point. Try our hijab looks to wear the second, embroidered dupatta to the back. So just cover your head (and hijab) with the dupatta and let the rest fall over your shoulders. This traditional style is popular for brides and formal occasions, exuding modesty and classic charm. Then neatly pleat the man, standard dupatta and place it over one shoulder. Pin it in place with a brooch or safety pin for a structured, formal appearance-perfect for weddings.
     

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 3.

 

Best Accessories for the Green Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

View our Green Bridal Collection for all options in this color.  Thoughtful accessorizing with jewelry, belts, and stylish dupatta draping further elevates the look, allowing for personalization and statement-making style. These elements together create a sharara that is elegant, comfortable, and uniquely eye-catching for any special occasion.

 

Contrasting with this Green Muslim Bridal Sharara is easy. View our Champagne Muslim Wedding Shop to find all your accessories that match the embroidery on this set.

This kaftan embraces a fusion of traditional and modern styles, with a focus on luxury and contemporary fashion trends. It has a V-neck and sleeves with gold embroidery on the cuffs. Blue Dubai Bridal Kaftan Product Description 

 

This is the last blue Islamic wedding dress of its kind, in XXL! Belt and matching bridal dupatta included. Find other Muslim bridal attire in blue in other sizes in our Blue Bridal Collection.

Blue Dubai Bridal Kaftan and Hijab

 

The Dubai kaftan, being a single-piece garment, is more versatile and can be worn with a hijab or shawl, like the one shown. Fabrics like chiffon, satin or silk are common for the hijab to complement the luxurious texture of the wedding kaftan.

 

The choice and style of head covering for Muslim wedding dresses can also reflect regional traditions and personal taste for your blue Islamic wedding dress, making the overall look more distinctive and expressive:
 

  • Wear your hijab in a classic Turkish style that wraps around the neck. Then drape a coordinating scarf or shawl (dupatta) over their hair or hijab for added elegance. You can find a contrasting dupatta in the Gold Muslim Wedding Shop.
     

  • Alternatively, you can wrap your hijab in a turban style for a chic, fashion-forward look. This style is especially popular for brides seeking a contemporary edge.

Accessories for the Blue Dubai Bridal Kaftan

 

You'll need heels for this look - no discussion. Then search our Gold Muslim Wedding Shop for lux nikkah jewelry and dupattas.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/422Bipt

 

History of the Muslim Kaftan

 

The kaftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. 

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

As Muslim wedding dresses, bridal sharara combines comfort, elegance, and cultural richness, making them a favored choice for Muslim brides seeking a regal yet practical wedding outfit. This well-tailored blue Muslim bridal sharara ensures ease of movement and comfort, making it ideal for long celebrations while maintaining a polished appearance.

 

A bridal sharara is a traditional three-piece ensemble typically worn by brides, consisting of a kurta or kameez (long or short top), a heavily flared pair of pants (sharara bottoms), and a dupatta. They are perfect to wear as Muslim wedding dresses and are distinguished by its opulent fabrics and luxurious embroidery that covers the sharara pants, kurta, and dupatta to create a regal and festive look.

How to Personalize your Teal Blue Muslim Bridal Sharara

 

The trending color of the Teal Blue Muslim Bridal Sharara is one step towards personalization, but your hairstyle and head covering are others. 

 

  • Try a sleek low bun for your hairstyle. A neat, polished bun at the nape of the neck highlights the shararaâ€™s embroidery and offers a timeless, sophisticated style. It also goes neatly under your hijab. 
  • Choose a hijab fabric and color that complements your shararaâ€™s fabric and embroidery-lightweight fabrics like chiffon, georgette, or silk work well to maintain elegance without adding bulk. 
  • Because your sharara is heavily adorned, choose a second dupatta that's lighter and sheer to avoid overpowering the ensemble. Wear the main, embroidered dupatta to the back. Then try the classic, one-shoulder drape for your second sheer dupatta. Just drape the dupatta over one shoulder and let it fall naturally on the front and side. Secure with a pin. This timeless style highlights the embroidery and border of the main dupatta while keeping the look graceful and sophisticated.

column7:
Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Our Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan uses elaborate, traditional embroidery in silver thread. There are two pieces to this wedding takchita when used as one of our Muslim wedding dresses: 

 

  • Tahtiya: An inner dress made of fine, shiny fabric that is long-sleeved and modest.
     
  • Dfina (or Fouqia): An outer, more elaborate over-dress, which is sheer and richly decorated with embroidery and metallic threadwork. 

 

Both have a fancy collar that layers one on top of the other, as the Moroccan caftan does.  It buttons up the front with traditional closures. Wear it with our rhinestone bridal belt. As one of our Muslim wedding dresses, it's worn by the bride and also for special occasions like weddings, Eid, and formal events. Find contrasting accessories and other bridal options in our Silver Muslim Wedding Shop. Jewelry and other bridal options in blue can be found in our Blue Bridal Collection.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ir1KyC

 

Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan Product Description 

 

This Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan comes in one size. This is 42 inches around the bust, and 46 around the hips. This blue Islamic wedding dress is hand-embroidered and 48 inches long.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ir1KyC

 

White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan and Hijab

 

Moroccan caftans are not always worn with hijab. If you're looking for a Moroccan Wedding Kaftan to wear as a blue Islamic wedding dress, it's easy to accommodate the difference. Head coverings can be coordinated in color and decoration with the takchita, enhancing the outfitâ€™s harmony and elevating its ceremonial appearance. Fabrics like chiffon, satin or silk are common for the hijab to complement the luxurious texture of the wedding caftan. The choice and style of head covering can also reflect regional traditions and personal taste, making the overall look more distinctive and expressive:

 

  • A popular and elegant way to wear a wedding caftan with a hijab is to tuck the hijab neatly into the neckline of the caftan. This style creates a seamless, modest look that highlights the intricate details of the caftanâ€™s neckline and embroidery while ensuring full coverage and comfort. The loose ends of the hijab are tucked inside the caftanâ€™s neckline or collar, giving a polished and clean finish.
     
  • If you don't like it tucked in, try a layered effect for volume.
     
  • Or wrap your hijab in a turban style or a wrap-around headscarf for a chic, fashion-forward look. This style is especially popular for brides seeking a contemporary edge.
     
  • Many women drape a coordinating scarf or shawl (dupatta) over their hair or hijab for added elegance. You can find a contrasting silver dupatta here.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ir1KyC

 

Accessories for the Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Traditional Moroccan bridal slippers are very similar to jutti. For the Blue Moroccan Wedding Kaftan, try our Silver Muslim Wedding Shop for jewelry, jutti and nails. Jewelry and other bridal options in blue can be found in our Blue Bridal Collection.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/41l53S5

 

History of the Muslim Caftan

 

The caftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. Not much has changed in the Moroccan kaftan design.

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

 

Introduced possibly in the late 15th or 16th century, influenced by Ottoman fashion through rulers, Moroccan kaftans became a symbol of cultural identity, evolving into both everyday and ceremonial wear with distinctive embroidery.
 

Yes, cultural pride, sis.

This Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara is a popular choice for bridal wear and for guests at weddings, as well as for other wedding functions like mehendi, walimah and engagement ceremonies. The regal look and ease of movement of these Muslim  wedding dresses makes them ideal for long celebrations.

 

Unlike other blue Islamic wedding dresses that have a skirt, this Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara is a traditional three-piece ensemble consisting of a kurta or kameez (long or short top), a heavily flared pair of pants (sharara bottoms) and a dupatta. View our Blue Bridal Collection for all options in this color.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 1.

 

Product Details for Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

Lightweight and airy, the net fabric in this sharara is used with heavy champagne-colored embroidery for a beautifully elegant touch. A somewhat crisp fabric, net is used to add volume and structure, often with embroidery that enhances its defined shape. Embellishments in champagne color are balanced between the pants and kurta with simple work on the dupatta for a cohesive ensemble in this Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara. The pants and top are heavily embroidered in floral patterns. So the embroidery on this set ranges from subtle to elaborate.

 

Sizes are measured at the bust in inches:(XXS-34),(XS-36),(S-38),(M-40),( L-42),( XL-44) and (XL-46). The top length is 37-39 inches for these Muslim wedding dresses.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 1.

 

Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara for Style and Comfort

 

The shararaâ€™s most significant cultural influence comes from the Muslim Mughal era in India, where it was a symbol of luxury, status and elegance among noblewomen and royalty. Its voluminous, flared silhouette and ornate embellishments reflected the grandeur of Mughal court fashion. Bridal shararas have deep cultural roots tracing back to the Mughal era and are especially popular among Muslim brides in South Asia as a blue Muslim wedding dress. 

 

Sharara dresses are especially preferred for occasions that call for traditional elegance and comfort. Shararas are preferred over other dresses for weddings, festive events and formal gatherings due to their comfort, elegance and rich cultural heritage. The signature wide-legged, flared pants are the defining feature, creating a graceful and dramatic look that distinguishes the bridal sharara from other ethnic outfits.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/3GGRjsi in color Choice 1.

 

How to Personalize your Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

When you select a pastel color like aqua, you can mix it with luxurious fabrics like georgette, silk for your dupatta and hijab. What about your hair?

 

  • This sharara begs for a braided crown, or just braids period for a regal, intricate look. Try braiding hair on both sides and pinning it across the crown, perfect for formal and traditional events, or wear a different braided updo.
     

  • To disguise your braided updo, you can wrap the hijab in a turban style for a chic, modern vibe! Or go for volume around the face. A graceful look, frame the hijab around your face with some volume on top by loosely wrapping or pleating the fabric, which pairs beautifully with the shararaâ€™s flared silhouette and makes braids less noticeable under your hijab.
     

  • Because your main dupatta is understated, wear a second dupatta with detailed embroidery, sequins, or a rich border to serve as a focal point. Try our hijab looks to wear the second, embroidered dupatta to the back. So just cover your head (and hijab) with the dupatta and let the rest fall over your shoulders. This traditional style is popular for brides and formal occasions, exuding modesty and classic charm. Then neatly pleat the man, standard dupatta and place it over one shoulder. Pin it in place with a brooch or safety pin for a structured, formal appearance-perfect for weddings.

Best Accessories for the Aqua Muslim Wedding Sharara

 

View our Blue Bridal Collection for all options in this color.  Thoughtful accessorizing with jewelry, belts, and stylish dupatta draping further elevates the look, allowing for personalization and statement-making style. These elements together create a sharara that is elegant, comfortable, and uniquely eye-catching for any special occasion.

Product Details for Aqua and Blue Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides

 

These Aqua and Blue Wedding Sharara for Muslim brides are perfect to use as Muslim wedding dresses. They are made from georgette fabric, which is known for being lightweight, making them easy to wear and comfortable for long celebrations. The fabricâ€™s fluidity and bounce create a flattering, elegant silhouette with beautiful movement, ideal for the flowing style of this bridal sharara. Despite its softness, the georgette is sturdy enough to hold the intricate embroidery, sequins and embellishments without sagging.

Aqua and Blue Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides Gives Style and Comfort

 

Bridal sharara suits were designed to accentuate elegance and grandeur, and as is often the case, this one is paired with an elaborately adorned kurta and dupatta. This ensembleâ€™s flowing lines and ornate details reflected the Muslim Mughal empire's appreciation for artistry and craftsmanship and can easily be worn as a blue Islamic wedding dress. Over time, the Mughal legacy ensured that shararas remained associated with celebration, aristocracy and cultural pride, influencing their continued popularity and adaptation in modern South Asian fashion.

 

The sharara is defined by its wide-legged, flared pants that start flaring from the waist and flow smoothly to the ankles, creating a skirt-like appearance. This is different from the gharara, which flares only from the knee, and from lehengas, which are single-piece skirts. Unlike the gharara, which has a visible seam or joint at the knee where the fabric is gathered or pleated for extra volume, the shararaâ€™s flare is continuous and seamless from the waist down. Shararas are known for their comfort and ease of movement due to the loose, flowing cut, making them ideal for weddings, and this one ideal as a blue Islamic wedding dress.

How to Personalize your Aqua and Blue Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides

 

This bridal sharara already blends heritage craftsmanship with modern aesthetics - combining classic embroidery with a contemporary aqua and blue color. But how else can you personalize the look?
 

  • A sleek bun with tendrils is easy to wear after you remove  your hijab, and the look with this vibrant color offers a sophisticated style, especially when paired with graceful dupatta draping.
     

  • For weddings, covering the head traditionally with the dupatta and pairing with a neatly styled hijab underneath can add modesty and grace. Just make sure to choose a lightweight fabric for your hijab and a few gold specks won't hurt.
     

  • A rhinestone bridal belt will set off this Aqua and Blue Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides.

column7:
Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Our Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan uses elaborate, traditional embroidery in gold thread. There are two pieces to this wedding takchita when used as Muslim wedding dresses: 

 

  • Tahtiya: An inner dress made of fine, shiny fabric that is long-sleeved and modest.
     
  • Dfina (or Fouqia): An outer, more elaborate over-dress, which is sheer and richly decorated with embroidery and metallic threadwork. 

 

Both have a fancy collar that layers one on top of the other, as the Moroccan caftan does.  It buttons up the front with traditional closures. Wear it with our rhinestone bridal belt. As Muslim wedding dresses, they are worn by the bride and also for special occasions like weddings, Eid, and formal events. Find accessories and other bridal options in our Gold Muslim Wedding Shop.

 

View current price and order on Amazon. https://amzn.to/3OOLtGi

 

Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan Product Description 

 

This Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan comes in one size. This is 46 inches around the bust. This gold Islamic bridal dress is covered in lace and is 56 inches long.

 

View current price and order on Amazon. https://amzn.to/3OOLtGi

 

Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan and Hijab

 

Moroccan caftans are not always worn with hijab. If you're looking for a Moroccan Wedding Kaftan to wear as a gold Islamic bridal dress, it's easy to accommodate the difference. Head coverings can be coordinated in color and decoration with the takchita, enhancing the outfitâ€™s harmony and elevating its ceremonial appearance. Fabrics like chiffon, satin or silk are common for the hijab to complement the luxurious texture of the wedding caftan. The choice and style of head covering can also reflect regional traditions and personal taste, making the overall look more distinctive and expressive:

 

  • A popular and elegant way to wear a wedding caftan with a hijab is to tuck the hijab neatly into the neckline of the caftan. This style creates a seamless, modest look that highlights the intricate details of the caftanâ€™s neckline and embroidery while ensuring full coverage and comfort. The loose ends of the hijab are tucked inside the caftanâ€™s neckline or collar, giving a polished and clean finish.
     
  • If you don't like it tucked in, try a layered effect for volume.
     
  • Or wrap your hijab in a turban style or a wrap-around headscarf for a chic, fashion-forward look. This style is especially popular for brides seeking a contemporary edge.
     
  • Many women drape a coordinating scarf or shawl (dupatta) over their hair or hijab for added elegance. You can find a gold dupatta here.

 

View current price and order on Amazon. https://amzn.to/3OOLtGi

 

Accessories for the Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Traditional Moroccan bridal slippers are very similar to jutti. For the Gold Moroccan Wedding Kaftan, try our Gold Muslim Wedding Shop for jewelry, jutti and dupattas.

 

View current price and order on Amazon. https://amzn.to/3OOLtGi

 

History of the Muslim Caftan

 

The caftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. Not much has changed in the Moroccan kaftan design.

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

 

Introduced possibly in the late 15th or 16th century, influenced by Ottoman fashion through rulers, Moroccan kaftans became a symbol of cultural identity, evolving into both everyday and ceremonial wear with distinctive embroidery.
 

Yes, cultural pride, sis.

column7:
Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Our Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan uses elaborate, traditional embroidery in silver thread. There are two pieces to this wedding takchita when used as Muslim wedding dresses: 

 

  • Tahtiya: An inner dress made of fine, shiny fabric that is long-sleeved and modest.
     
  • Dfina (or Fouqia): An outer, more elaborate over-dress, which is sheer and richly decorated with embroidery and metallic threadwork. 

 

Both have a fancy collar that layers one on top of the other, as the Moroccan caftan does.  It buttons up the front with traditional closures. Wear it with our rhinestone bridal belt. As one of our Muslim wedding dresses, it's worn by the bride and also for special occasions like weddings, Eid, and formal events. View our other bridal options like lilac Muslim wedding lehengas in the Lilac Wedding Collection. Find contrasting accessories and other bridal options in our Silver Muslim Wedding Shop.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4iDrLty

 

Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan Product Description 

 

This Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan comes in one size. This is 44 inches around the bust, in satin, with 20 inch sleeves. This lavender Islamic wedding dress is hand-embroidered with silver threads and cut out lace and is 56 inches long.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4iDrLty

 

Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan and Hijab

 

Moroccan caftans are not always worn with hijab. If you're looking for a Moroccan Wedding Kaftan to wear as a lavender Islamic wedding dress, it's easy to accommodate the difference. Head coverings can be coordinated in color and decoration with the takchita, enhancing the outfitâ€™s harmony and elevating its ceremonial appearance. Fabrics like chiffon, satin or silk are common for the hijab to complement the luxurious texture of the wedding caftan. The choice and style of head covering can also reflect regional traditions and personal taste, making the overall look more distinctive and expressive:

 

  • A popular and elegant way to wear a wedding caftan with a hijab is to tuck the hijab neatly into the neckline of the caftan. This style creates a seamless, modest look that highlights the intricate details of the caftanâ€™s neckline and embroidery while ensuring full coverage and comfort. The loose ends of the hijab are tucked inside the caftanâ€™s neckline or collar, giving a polished and clean finish.
     
  • If you don't like it tucked in, try a layered effect for volume.
     
  • Or wrap your hijab in a turban style or a wrap-around headscarf for a chic, fashion-forward look. This style is especially popular for brides seeking a contemporary edge.
     
  • Many women drape a coordinating scarf or shawl (dupatta) over their hair or hijab for added elegance. You can find a contrasting silver dupatta in the Silver Muslim Wedding Shop.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4iDrLty

 

Accessories for the Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Traditional Moroccan bridal slippers are very similar to jutti. For the Lavender Moroccan Wedding Kaftan, try our Silver Muslim Wedding Shop for jewelry, jutti and nails. Or view our other bridal options like the lilac Muslim wedding lehenga in our Lilac Wedding Collection.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4iDrLty

 

History of the Muslim Caftan

 

The caftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. Not much has changed in the Moroccan kaftan design.

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

 

Introduced possibly in the late 15th or 16th century, influenced by Ottoman fashion through rulers, Moroccan kaftans became a symbol of cultural identity, evolving into both everyday and ceremonial wear with distinctive embroidery.
 

Yes, cultural pride, sis.

column7:
Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides

 

This Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides is a perfect choice for its feminine color and aesthetics. While most peach Muslim bridal dresses have a long, flared skirt, sharara use wide-legged pants that are similar to palazzo. The structure and styling set bridal sharara apart, but check our Peach Wedding Collection for all options in this color.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ipCrwE.

 

Product Details for Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides

 

These Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim brides is perfect to use for Muslim wedding dresses. They are made from georgette fabric, which is known for being lightweight, making them easy to wear and comfortable for long celebrations. The fabricâ€™s fluidity and bounce create a flattering, elegant silhouette with beautiful movement, ideal for the flowing style of this bridal sharara. Despite its softness, the georgette is sturdy enough to hold the intricate embroidery, sequins and embellishments without sagging.

 

Sizes are measured at the bust in inches: Small= 36 (Inch) || Medium=38 (Inch) || Large=40 (Inch) || XL=42 (Inch) || XXL=44 (Inch). The top and bottom lengths are 40  inches for these Muslim wedding dresses. 

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ipCrwE.

 

Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides Gives Style and Comfort

 

Bridal sharara suits were designed to accentuate elegance and grandeur, and as is often the case, this one is paired with an elaborately adorned kurta and dupatta. This ensembleâ€™s flowing lines and ornate details reflected the Muslim Mughal empire's appreciation for artistry and craftsmanship and can easily be worn as a peach Muslim bridal dress. Over time, the Mughal legacy ensured that shararas remained associated with celebration, aristocracy and cultural pride, influencing their continued popularity and adaptation in modern South Asian fashion.

 

The sharara is defined by its wide-legged, flared pants that start flaring from the waist and flow smoothly to the ankles, creating a skirt-like appearance. This is different from the gharara, which flares only from the knee, and from lehengas, which are single-piece skirts. Unlike the gharara, which has a visible seam or joint at the knee where the fabric is gathered or pleated for extra volume, the shararaâ€™s flare is continuous and seamless from the waist down. Shararas are known for their comfort and ease of movement due to the loose, flowing cut, making them ideal for weddings, and this one ideal as a peach Muslim bridal dress.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/4ipCrwE.

 

How to Personalize your Peach Wedding Sharara for Muslim Brides

 

This bridal sharara already blends heritage craftsmanship with modern aesthetics - combining classic embroidery with a contemporary peach color. But how else can you personalize the look?

 

  • A messy bun is easy to wear after you remove  your hijab, and the look with this pastel color offers a bohemian yet sophisticated style, especially when paired with graceful dupatta draping.
     

  • For weddings, covering the head traditionally with the dupatta and pair it with a neatly styled hijab underneath can add modesty and grace. Just make sure to choose a lightweight fabric for your hijab and a few gold specks won't hurt.
     

  • Select a second dupatta with complementary hues and patterns that synchronize with your main sharara dupatta. Maroon and silver work perfectly! Wear the main dupatta over your head, and the extra, light one over your shoulder. You can even accordion it and tuck it into a bridal belt. Contrasting or matching colors can both work, depending on whether you want a bold or harmonious look.

View our Peach Wedding Collection for all options in this color. Choose bold pieces like chandelier earrings and a choker necklace to enhance the regal look of your sharara. Heavy earrings, layered necklaces, and beaded or metallic bangles add elegance and draw attention to your ensemble. Embellished juttis or metallic-toned sandals also work well for a traditional yet stylish touch.

Product Details for Maroon Muslim Bridal Sharara

 

These are a ready-made garments in three pieces made from soft net and adapts easily as Muslim wedding dresses. The net fabric drapes beautifully and adds elegance without adding bulk. It is heavily embroidered in floral patterns. Embroidery highlights the flared pants, kurta, and dupatta, with artistic work distributed across all pieces.

Maroon Muslim Bridal Sharara for Style and Comfort

 

This Maroon Muslim Bridal Sharara provides a unique blend of traditional Mughal-era royal style with modern, pastel-color elegance, making the bride stand out on her special day. The Mughal embroidery technique on such red Muslim wedding dresses uses a pen-like needle for fine, intricate threadwork, sometimes combined with sequins or stones for extra richness. 

 

As Muslim wedding dresses, bridal sharara combine comfort, elegance, and cultural richness, making them a favored choice for Muslim brides seeking a regal yet practical wedding outfit. This well-tailored sharara ensures ease of movement and comfort, making it ideal for long celebrations while maintaining a polished appearance.

 

A bridal sharara is a traditional three-piece ensemble typically worn by brides, consisting of a kurta or kameez (long or short top), a heavily flared pair of pants (sharara bottoms), and a dupatta. They are perfect to wear as Muslim wedding dresses and are distinguished by opulent fabrics and luxurious embroidery that covers the sharara pants, kurta, and dupatta to create a regal and festive look.

 

Vibrant or pastel hues, often paired with metallic accents, enhance the visual appeal and can be tailored to match the event or personal style.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/436wob0 in Maroon.

 

How to Personalize your Maroon Muslim Bridal Sharara

 

Choosing the vibrant traditional color of the  Maroon Muslim Bridal Sharara is one step personalization, but your hairstyle and head covering are others. 

 

  • Try a sleek low bun for your hairstyle. A neat, polished bun at the nape of the neck highlights the shararaâ€™s embroidery and offers a timeless, sophisticated style. It also goes neatly under your hijab. 
  • Choose a hijab fabric and color that complements your shararaâ€™s fabric and embroidery-lightweight fabrics like chiffon, georgette, or silk work well to maintain elegance without adding bulk. 
  • Because your sharara is heavily adorned, choose a second dupatta that's lighter and sheer to avoid overpowering the ensemble. Wear the main, embroidered dupatta to the back. Then try the classic, one-shoulder drape for your second sheer dupatta. Just drape the dupatta over one shoulder and let it fall naturally on the front and side. Secure with a pin. This timeless style highlights the embroidery and border of the main dupatta while keeping the look graceful and sophisticated.

History of the Muslim Kaftan

 

The kaftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. 

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

column7:
White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Our White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan uses elaborate, traditional embroidery in silver thread. There are two pieces to this wedding takchita when used as Muslim wedding dresses: 

 

  • Tahtiya: An inner dress made of fine, shiny fabric that is long-sleeved and modest.
     
  • Dfina (or Fouqia): An outer, more elaborate over-dress, which is sheer and richly decorated with embroidery and metallic threadwork. 

 

Both have a fancy collar that layers one on top of the other, as the Moroccan caftan does.  It buttons up the front with traditional closures. This White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan features a belt (mdamma) to accentuate the waist. As Muslim wedding dresses, they are worn by the bride and also for special occasions like weddings, Eid, and formal events. Find your accessories and other bridal options in white in our White Muslim Wedding Shop.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/41l53S5

 

White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan Product Description 

 

This outfit traditionally comes in one size, and a belt is used with it to gather the fabric. This is 46 inches around the bust, and 50 around the hips. This White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan is hand-embroidered and 56 inches long.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/41l53S5

 

White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan and Hijab

 

Moroccan caftans are not always worn with hijab. If you're looking for a white Moroccan Wedding Kaftan to wear as a white hijab wedding dress, it's easy to accommodate the difference. Head coverings can be coordinated in color and decoration with the takchita, enhancing the outfitâ€™s harmony and elevating its ceremonial appearance. Fabrics like chiffon, satin or silk are common for the hijab to complement the luxurious texture of the wedding caftan.The choice and style of head covering can also reflect regional traditions and personal taste, making the overall look more distinctive and expressive:

 

  • A popular and elegant way to wear a white hijab wedding dress is to tuck the hijab neatly into the neckline of the caftan. This style creates a seamless, modest look that highlights the intricate details of the caftanâ€™s neckline and embroidery while ensuring full coverage and comfort. The loose ends of the hijab are tucked inside the caftanâ€™s neckline or collar, giving a polished and clean finish.
  • If you don't like it tucked in, try a layered effect for volume.
     
  • Or wrap your hijab in a turban style or a wrap-around headscarf for a chic, fashion-forward look. This style is especially popular for brides seeking a contemporary edge.
     
  • Many women drape a coordinating scarf or shawl (dupatta) over their hair or hijab for added elegance. You can find a matching dupatta in the White Muslim Wedding Shop, or browse our other collections for a contrasting red or silver dupatta.  

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/41l53S5

 

Accessories for the White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan

 

Traditional Moroccan bridal slippers are very similar to jutti. For the White Moroccan Wedding Kaftan, search our White Muslim Wedding Shop for jutti and nails. Try our Silver Muslim Wedding Shop for jewelry.

 

View price and purchase on Amazon: https://amzn.to/41l53S5

 

History of the Muslim Caftan

 

The caftan became prominent during the Abbasid Caliphate (8thâ€“13th centuries), where it was a luxurious garment worn by caliphs and aristocrats, often made of silver or gold brocade with decorative buttons. Not much has changed in the Moroccan kaftan design.

 

The kaftan symbolized rank and status. Ottoman sultans wore elaborately decorated kaftans, often gifted to dignitaries. The Ottoman Empire (1299â€“1922) popularized the kaftan across the Middle East and Mediterranean. Ottoman kaftans featured rich fabrics like velvet and silk, with intricate embroidery and specific colors indicating the wearerâ€™s rank.

 

Introduced possibly in the late 15th or 16th century, influenced by Ottoman fashion through rulers, Moroccan kaftans became a symbol of cultural identity, evolving into both everyday and ceremonial wear with distinctive embroidery.
 

Yes, cultural pride, sis.
